text: well we all felt it here in Rome the
building shook tremendously at 7:40 in
the morning it turns out that the
epicenter was about a hundred miles or
so north of here in central Italy not
far from the epicentre of previous
quakes the quake in August which killed
nearly a three hundred people and two
quakes on Wednesday which caused
extensive damage which which didn't kill
anyone the civil protection authorities
are still trying to work out how many
people may have been left homeless
homeless which buildings may have come
down the town of nadia appears to have
been hit we've seen that the good that
the town's church has come down monks
and nuns have been gathering in the town
square obviously you know traumatic
thing to go through for four people
there especially after what's happened
what's the reaction been I I think
people were expecting this I went to the
aftermath of both previous earthquakes
the one this week in the one in August
and there was a great sense of fear but
it was also great since both times that
this was not yet over one woman who
spoke to us on Thursday from one of the
affected area said what are we going to
do now and I think a lot of those people
will simply have been too scared to go
back to their homes it may be that that
was a very wise decision that people who
decided not to go back to two homes with
cracks in the walls chose wisely in that
they were away from those buildings when
this morning's earthquake is it too soon
to assess the damage and casualties
potentially I think that's going on all
the time it is least civil protection
authorities will be calling up all the
mayor's in this particular region bear
in mind it's a reasonably inaccessible
area that winding winding roads on
hillsides and you see towns clinging
ancient towns clinging to the top of
hillsides so civil protection
authorities will want to be checking in
with all the mayor's if there's mobile
phone coverage to see what kind of
damage there is and well I would imagine
we'll also see a lot of teams out on the
roads clearing rocks from the roads to
make sure that if relief work needs to
be done that those roads are accessible
